ground_truth: He climbs in. The car belches and pops and toodles off down the road. Delmar staggers to his feet and stumbles over to the carcass of the frog, weeping. His arms, stretched high over his head, are tied to a tree limb. His interrogator wields a bullwhip. Another lash, another scream. A third man walks into the torchlight, a hound drooling at his heels. He is Cooley, the sheriff with mirrored sunglasses whom we remember from previous barn confrontations. The two men acknowledge by backing away from Pete and then the accelerating pitter-patter of arriving rain. Cooley looks up. He looks back down at Pete. He shrugs, looks off. Looking up, into black: a rope is tossed up - it recedes out of the torchlight into black night - and then drops back down into the light, a noose bouncing at its end. The two henchmen fit the noose over Pete's neck. Delmar doggedly shakes his head. We distantly hear picks ringing and male chanting. Hollow-eyed, Everett tries to convince himself as much as Delmar. His voice trails away as he looks out at the road. They are passing a line of chained men in prison stripes and duck-billed caps wielding pickaxes and shovels at the side of the road. As he stares at the line of men Everett tries to pick up his thread. The prisoners look like phantoms in the heat and dust. Everett is haunted. The last man in line swings his pick and, as he grows smaller, looks up. Everett stares. Lone and lorn, he returns Everett's slack-jawed stare until heat ripples and the truck's dusty wake dissolve him away. Everett blinks. Everett shakes his head as if to clear it. The truck rattles on. On a bunting-covered stage, a pencil-necked man with round rimless glasses addresses a crowd of rustics. The pencil-neck is identified on posters as 'Homer Stokes, Friend of the Little Man', and, in life as in the pictures, he shakes a broom over his head. A midget in overalls stands next to him. The midget waves his little midget broom in time with Stoke's waves. He beams amid cheers and then, as three girls in gingham frocks run out to join him. The oldest girl is about ten. Everett stomps toward the stage, fighting his way through the crowd. Puzzled, Delmar follows. A man in a straw boater joins them. Everett sniffs and, catching a scent, squints. With this he takes a wild swing which Waldrip easily eludes. Waldrip adapts a Marquess of Queensbury stance and prances about, delivering stinging punches to the nose of a stunned and outclassed Everett. Its glass doors swing open and Everett is hurled out and bellyflops into the dust of the street.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: He climbs into the vehicle. The car, with a cacophony of belches and pops, toodles off down the road, leaving a trail of noise in its wake. Meanwhile, Delmar, struggling to regain his balance, staggers to his feet and stumbles over to the lifeless carcass of the frog, tears streaming down his face. His arms, stretched high above his head, are securely tied to a tree limb, rendering him helpless. His interrogator, a menacing figure, wields a bullwhip with a practiced hand. With each lash, another scream pierces the air. A third man, shrouded in the flickering torchlight, walks into view, a hound drooling at his heels. This man is Cooley, the sheriff with mirrored sunglasses, a familiar face from previous barn confrontations. The two men acknowledge each other by backing away from Pete, and then the accelerating pitter-patter of arriving rain fills the air. Cooley looks up at the sky, then back down at Pete. He shrugs nonchalantly and looks off into the distance. As he gazes upward into the inky blackness, a rope is tossed up, disappearing momentarily into the darkness before dropping back down into the light, a noose bouncing ominously at its end. The two henchmen methodically fit the noose over Pete's neck. Delmar, with a determined expression, doggedly shakes his head. In the distance, the sound of picks ringing and male chanting can be heard faintly. Hollow-eyed, Everett tries to convince himself as much as Delmar, his voice trailing away as he looks out at the road. They are passing a line of chained men, clad in prison stripes and duck-billed caps, wielding pickaxes and shovels at the side of the road. As Everett stares at the line of men, he tries to pick up his thread of thought. The prisoners appear like phantoms, ghostly figures in the oppressive heat and swirling dust. Everett is haunted by the sight. The last man in line swings his pick and, as he grows smaller in the distance, looks up. Everett stares back, transfixed. Lone and lorn, the man returns Everett's slack-jawed stare until the heat ripples and the truck's dusty wake dissolve him away into nothingness. Everett blinks, trying to clear his mind. He shakes his head as if to dispel the haunting images. The truck rattles on, continuing its journey. On a bunting-covered stage, a pencil-necked man with round rimless glasses addresses a crowd of rustics. This pencil-neck is identified on posters as 'Homer Stokes, Friend of the Little Man', and, in life as in the pictures, he energetically shakes a broom over his head. A midget in overalls stands next to him, waving his little midget broom in time with Stokes's enthusiastic waves. He beams amid the cheers of the crowd, and then, as if on cue, three girls in gingham frocks run out to join him. The oldest girl appears to be about ten years old. Everett, with determination, stomps toward the stage, fighting his way through the throng of people. Puzzled, Delmar follows closely behind. A man in a straw boater joins them, adding to the commotion. Everett sniffs the air and, catching a familiar scent, squints with suspicion. With this, he takes a wild swing, which Waldrip easily eludes with practiced agility. Waldrip, adopting a Marquess of Queensbury stance, prances about, delivering stinging punches to the nose of a stunned and clearly outclassed Everett. The glass doors swing open, and Everett is unceremoniously hurled out, bellyflopping into the dust of the street, a cloud of dirt rising around him.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: He gingerly climbs into the vehicle, settling into the seat with care. The old car, an unreliable machine known for its cacophony of belches and pops, toodles off down the narrow, winding road, leaving behind a trail of noise and echoes in its wake. Meanwhile, Delmar, struggling to regain his footing, staggers slowly to his feet. He then stumbles over to where the lifeless carcass of the frog lies, tears streaming unchecked down his face. His arms, extended high above his head, are securely tied to a sturdy tree limb, rendering him helpless and immobilized. His interrogator, a menacing and intimidating figure, wields a bullwhip with a practiced and ruthless hand. With each crack of the whip, another scream brutally pierces the thick, suffocating air. A third man, shrouded in the flickering, shifting torchlight, emerges into view, a hound drooling menacingly at his heels. This man is Cooley, the sheriff with mirrored sunglasses, a familiar face from previous intense barn confrontations. The two men acknowledge one another by backing warily away from Pete, and then the accelerating pitter-patter of arriving rain begins to fill the air, growing louder. Cooley looks up at the ominous sky, then back down at Pete. He nonchalantly shrugs and looks contemplatively off into the distance. As he gazes upward into the inky, impenetrable blackness, a rope is tossed briskly up, disappearing momentarily into the darkness before dropping back down into the light, a sinister noose bouncing ominously at its end. The two henchmen methodically fit the noose over Pete's neck with unsettling precision. Delmar, with a determined and resolute expression, doggedly shakes his head in disbelief. In the distance, the faint sound of picks ringing and male chanting can be heard, drifting softly on the wind. Hollow-eyed and weary, Everett tries to convince himself as much as Delmar, his voice trailing away into the silence as he looks distraughtly out at the road. They are passing a line of chained men, clad in bleak prison stripes and wearing duck-billed caps, wielding pickaxes and shovels by the side of the dusty road. As Everett stares at the line of men, he struggles to pick up his thread of thought, feeling a sense of despair. The prisoners appear like spectral phantoms, ghostly figures moving in the oppressive heat and swirling, choking dust. Everett is haunted by the sight of them. The last man in line swings his pick and, as he gradually grows smaller in the distance, looks up. Everett stares back, utterly transfixed. Lone and lorn, the man returns Everett's slack-jawed stare until, at last, the heat waves and the truck's dusty wake dissolve him away into nothingness. Everett blinks several times, trying desperately to clear his mind. He shakes his head vigorously as if to dispel the haunting, vivid images. The truck rattles noisily on, continuing its journey down the road. On a bunting-covered stage, a pencil-necked man with round rimless glasses addresses a crowd of eager rustics. This pencil-neck is identified on colorful posters as 'Homer Stokes, Friend of the Little Man,' and, in life as in the pictures, he energetically waves a broom above his head. A midget in overalls stands next to him, enthusiastically waving his little midget broom in perfect time with Stokes's enthusiastic, rhythmic gestures. He beams broadly amid the loud cheers of the jubilant crowd, and then, as if perfectly on cue, three girls in blue gingham frocks run energetically out to join him. The oldest girl appears to be around ten years old. Everett, filled with determination, stomps purposefully toward the stage, fighting his way through the dense throng of people. Puzzled by Everett's urgency, Delmar follows closely behind him, unsure of what to expect. A man wearing a straw boater joins them, adding to the growing commotion. Everett, sniffing the air instinctively and catching a familiar scent, squints suspiciously with narrowed eyes. With this sense of suspicion, he takes a wild swing, which Waldrip easily and gracefully eludes with practiced agility. Waldrip, adopting a Marquess of Queensbury stance, begins to prance about, delivering stinging punches to the nose of a stunned and clearly outclassed Everett. The glass doors swing open with force, and Everett is unceremoniously hurled out, bellyflopping with a thud into the dust of the street, a cloud of dirt rising around him in the aftermath.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: He climbs in to a rusty old car, a relic of the past, sputtering and emitting loud pops as it toodles off down the potholed road. Delmar staggers to his feet, his unsteady gait revealing his distress, and stumbles over to the carcass of the frog, a symbol of lost hope, weeping. His arms, stretched high over his head in a painful suspension, are tied to a tree limb, reminiscent of frontier justice. His interrogator, a hulking figure dressed in worn leather, wields a bullwhip, an intimidating weapon that cracks through the night air. Another lash, another scream echoing through the woods. A third man, a looming presence, walks into the torchlight, a hound slavering at his heels. He is Cooley, the sheriff known for his mirrored sunglasses which reflect the fear of those he confronts, whom we remember from previous barn confrontations. The two men acknowledge a decision by backing away from Pete, and then the accelerating pitter-patter of arriving rain heralds a coming storm. Cooley looks up, the rain spotting his lenses. He looks back down at Pete, calculating. He shrugs, looks off into the distance. Looking up, into the blackness of the night sky: a rope is tossed up - it recedes out of the torchlight into the ink-black night - and then drops back down into the light, a noose bouncing ominously at its end. The two henchmen, their faces shadowed and grim, fit the noose over Pete's neck. Delmar doggedly shakes his head, refusing to give in to despair. We distantly hear picks ringing and male chanting, a haunting echo of the chain gang labor often seen in the South. Hollow-eyed, Everett tries to convince himself as much as Delmar, his voice a mere whisper of assurance. His voice trails away as he looks out at the road, lost in his thoughts. They are passing a line of chained men in prison stripes and duck-billed caps, reminiscent of 1930s convict attire, wielding pickaxes and shovels at the side of the road. As he stares at the line of men, Everett tries to pick up his thread of hope. The prisoners, appearing ghostly in the sweltering heat and swirling dust, look like phantoms in this desolate landscape. Everett is haunted by their plight. The last man in line swings his pick and, as he grows smaller, looks up with a distant, knowing gaze. Everett stares, as if recognizing a shared hardship. Lone and lorn, he returns Everett's slack-jawed stare until heat ripples and the truck's dusty wake dissolve him away, a mirage of despair. Everett blinks, trying to shake off the vision. Everett shakes his head as if to clear it, dismissing the haunting sight. The truck rattles on, its engine a low grumble. On a bunting-covered stage in the heart of a small town fair, a pencil-necked man with round rimless glasses, reminiscent of old political figures, addresses a crowd of rustics gathered for entertainment. The pencil-neck is identified on posters plastered around the venue as 'Homer Stokes, Friend of the Little Man', and, in life as in the pictures, he shakes a broom over his head, symbolizing a sweeping change. A midget in overalls, a figure often seen as a curiosity in the past, stands next to him. The midget waves his little midget broom in time with Stoke's waves, a choreographed display of unity. He beams amid cheers and then, as three girls in gingham frocks reminiscent of rural innocence, run out to join him. The oldest girl is about ten, full of youthful enthusiasm. Everett stomps toward the stage, determination in his stride, fighting his way through the crowd. Puzzled, Delmar follows, ever loyal. A man in a straw boater, a fashion choice from the early 20th century, joins them. Everett sniffs and, catching a suspicious scent, squints in sudden clarity. With this he takes a wild swing, an act of sudden aggression, which Waldrip, a man with a slick veneer, easily eludes. Waldrip adapts a Marquess of Queensbury stance, a style of boxing known for its elegance, and prances about, delivering stinging punches to the nose of a stunned and outclassed Everett. Its glass doors swing open, and Everett is hurled out with force, bellyflopping into the dust of the street as onlookers gasp at his fall.

He is Cooley, the sheriff with mirrored sunglasses whom we remember from previous barn celebrations. The two men acknowledge by shuffling away from Pete and then the accelerating drizzle of departing rain. Cooley gazes up. He glances back down at Pete. He sighs, looks aside. Gazing up, into black: a rope is flung upward - it expands out of the torchlight into black night - and then dangles back down into the light, a knot bouncing at its end. The two henchmen place the knot over Pete's neck. Delmar eagerly nods his head. We distantly hear drums clattering and female humming. Bright-eyed, Everett tries to amuse himself as much as Delmar. His voice trails away as he gazes out at the road. They are witnessing a line of dancing men in prison stripes and duck-billed caps wielding instruments and brushes at the side of the road. As he observes the line of men Everett tries to catch his rhythm. The men resemble specters in the mist and shadows. Everett is intrigued. The last man in line swings his brush and, as he grows larger, glances up. Everett watches. Lone and lorn, he returns Everett's wide-eyed stare until heat waves and the truck's smoky wake blend him away. Everett blinks. Everett tilts his head as if to reset it. The truck purrs on. On a ribbon-decked stage, a pencil-necked man with round rimless glasses entertains a crowd of rustics. The pencil-neck is identified on posters as 'Homer Stokes, Enemy of the Tall Man', and, in life as in the pictures, he waves a fan over his head. A midget in overalls dances next to him. The midget twirls his little midget fan in time with Stoke's waves. He glows amid cheers and then, as three girls in gingham frocks waltz out to join him. The oldest girl is about ten. test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption

Her interrogator wields a feather duster. Another tickle, another giggle. A third cupcake strolls into the moonlight, a cat purring at its toes. It is Willoughby, the gardener with mirrored binoculars whom we recall from previous attic discussions. The two bananas acknowledge by backing away from Martha and then the accelerating drip-drop of arriving hail. Willoughby glances up. He glances back down at Martha. He shrugs, peers off. Glancing up, into gray: a vine is tossed up - it recedes out of the moonlight into gray midnight - and then drops back down into the light, a pretzel bouncing at its end. The two vagrants fit the pretzel over Martha’s wrist. Gertrude unflinchingly shakes her knee. We distantly hear drums tolling and female chanting. Hollow-eyed, Jasper tries to convince himself as much as Gertrude. His whisper trails away as he gazes out at the garden. Its wooden gates swing closed and Everett is tossed out and backflips into the mud of the street.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The rabbit leaps in. The tractor coughs and sputters and meanders off up the lane. Baxter sways to his paws and crawls over to the skeleton of the pigeon, wailing. His legs, lifted high over his shoulders, are fastened to a bush branch. His tormentor brandishes a lasso. Another swing, another howl. A fourth rabbit hops into the moonlight, a cat slobbering at its paws. He is Carter, the mayor with shiny monocles whom we recall from earlier shed encounters. The three animals nod by creeping away from Jerry and then the quickening tinkle-tinkle of incoming hail. Carter glances upward. He peers back at Jerry. He sighs, gazes away. Gazing upward, into white: a chain is flung up - it shrinks out of the moonlight into white dusk - and then returns back down into the glow, a knot bobbing at its tip. The three guards slip the knot over Jerry's ear. Baxter persistently wobbles his ears. We faintly hear drums pounding and female yelling. Bleary-eyed, Lawrence attempts to encourage himself as much as Baxter. His eyes drift away as he surveys the lane. They are moving past a row of tethered owls in striped pajamas and long-brimmed hats holding mallets and rakes at the edge of the lane. As he peers at the row of owls Lawrence struggles to resume his discourse. The convicts resemble shadows in the warmth and grime. Lawrence is troubled. The leading owl in the row swings its mallet and, as it becomes tinier, glances upward. Lawrence gapes. Solo and forlorn, it maintains Lawrence's wide-eyed gawk until haze shimmers and the wagon's muddy trail erases it away. Lawrence squints. Lawrence wobbles his ears as if to reset it. The wagon clatters on. On a floral-draped platform, a string-beaned bird with square frameless goggles addresses a flock of peasants. The string-bean is listed on billboards as 'Barney Jones, Ally of the Giant Creature', and, in reality as in the portraits, he waves a feather over his legs. A miniature in jeans stands beside him. The miniature flaps its tiny miniature feather in rhythm with Jones's flaps. He grins among shouts and then, as five boys in denim pants dash out to join him. The eldest boy is about twelve. Lawrence charges at the platform, pushing his path through the flock. Confounded, Baxter tags along. A bird in a woven bonnet joins them. Lawrence inhales and, catching an odor, gasps. With that he unleashes a frantic swipe which Dominic effortlessly dodges. Dominic assumes a Regal of Wimbledon posture and flits around, delivering sharp jabs to the eyebrow of a baffled and outplayed Lawrence. Its wooden flaps swing wide and Lawrence is tossed out and bellyflops into the grime of the avenue.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: The car departs with a series of noisy sounds, leaving Delmar to mourn a crushed frog. Tied to a tree, Pete is whipped by an interrogator, and Sheriff Cooley, recognized from earlier confrontations, approaches with his dog. A noose is placed around Pete's neck as rain begins. Everett, hollow-eyed, watches chained prisoners in stripes working by the road. He's transfixed by a phantom-like figure staring back until it vanishes in the dust. On stage, Homer Stokes, known as 'Friend of the Little Man,' rallies a crowd, shaking a broom with a midget beside him. Everett fights through the crowd to confront Stokes but is easily outmaneuvered, ultimately thrown out onto the street.
